articles.headline: The Death of the Department Store: ‘Very Few Are Likely to Survive’
articles.snippet: Shuttered flagships. Empty malls. Canceled orders. Risks of bankruptcy. The coronavirus has hit the behemoths of the retail world.
articles.abstract: Shuttered flagships. Empty malls. Canceled orders. Risks of bankruptcy. The coronavirus has hit the behemoths of the retail world.
articles.lead_paragraph: American department stores, once all-powerful shopping meccas that anchored malls and Main Streets across the country, have been dealt blow after blow in the past decade. J.C. Penney and Sears were upended by hedge funds. Macy’s has been closing stores and cutting corporate staff. Barneys New York filed for bankruptcy last year.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Senate Approves Aid for Small-Business Loan Program, Hospitals and Testing
articles.snippet: The Senate passed a $484 billion relief package, after Democrats and Trump administration officials finalized an agreement.
articles.abstract: The Senate passed a $484 billion relief package, after Democrats and Trump administration officials finalized an agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved a $484 billion coronavirus relief package on Tuesday that would revive a depleted loan program for distressed small businesses and provide funds for hospitals and coronavirus testing, breaking a partisan impasse over the latest infusion of federal money to address the public health and economic crisis brought on by the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Trump (the Company) Asks Trump (the Administration) for Hotel Relief
articles.snippet: The president’s family business pays at least $3 million a year to the federal government for the lease on its D.C. hotel, which is all but empty because of the virus. The next monthly payment is coming due.
articles.abstract: The president’s family business pays at least $3 million a year to the federal government for the lease on its D.C. hotel, which is all but empty because of the virus. The next monthly payment is coming due.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s signature hotel in the nation’s capital wants a break on the terms of its lease. The landlord determining the fate of the request is Mr. Trump’s own administration.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Steve Eder and David Enrich

articles.headline: The Quiet Hand of Conservative Groups in the Anti-Lockdown Protests
articles.snippet: Groups in a loose coalition have tapped their networks to drive up turnout at recent rallies in state capitals and financed lawsuits, polling and research to combat the stay-at-home orders.
articles.abstract: Groups in a loose coalition have tapped their networks to drive up turnout at recent rallies in state capitals and financed lawsuits, polling and research to combat the stay-at-home orders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An informal coalition of influential conservative leaders and groups, some with close connections to the White House, has been quietly working to nurture protests and apply political and legal pressure to overturn state and local orders intended to stop the spread of the coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Jim Rutenberg and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: ‘I’m Just Living a Nightmare’: Oil Industry Braces for Devastation
articles.snippet: Across the United States, companies are laying off workers, shutting down wells and preparing for a prolonged slump as oil prices tumble.
articles.abstract: Across the United States, companies are laying off workers, shutting down wells and preparing for a prolonged slump as oil prices tumble.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Workers at Marathon Petroleum’s refinery in Gallup, N.M., are turning off the valves. Oil companies in West Texas are paying early termination fees to contract employees rather than drill new wells. And in Montana, producers are shutting down wells and slashing salaries and benefits.

articles.headline: Trump Halts New Green Cards, but Backs Off Broader Immigration Ban
articles.snippet: After pledging on Twitter to end immigration during the pandemic, President Trump moved to block new green cards but stopped short of ending all work visas.
articles.abstract: After pledging on Twitter to end immigration during the pandemic, President Trump moved to block new green cards but stopped short of ending all work visas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Tuesday that he would order a temporary halt in issuing green cards to prevent people from immigrating to the United States, but he backed away from plans to suspend guest worker programs after business groups exploded in anger at the threat of losing access to foreign labor.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: Covid-19 Arrived in Seattle. Where It Went From There Stunned the Scientists.
articles.snippet: Scientists traced the virus brought to the Seattle area in January. They were astonished to learn that the same branch of the virus traveled on through at least a dozen states and to other parts of the world.
articles.abstract: Scientists traced the virus brought to the Seattle area in January. They were astonished to learn that the same branch of the virus traveled on through at least a dozen states and to other parts of the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — As the coronavirus outbreak consumed the city of Wuhan in China, new cases of the virus began to spread out like sparks flung from a fire.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker and Sheri Fink

articles.headline: Oil Collapse and Covid-19 Create Toxic Geopolitical Stew
articles.snippet: For nations reliant on oil sales, the combination of the price collapse and the coronavirus pandemic has created new threats of poverty and political instability from Iraq to Venezuela.
articles.abstract: For nations reliant on oil sales, the combination of the price collapse and the coronavirus pandemic has created new threats of poverty and political instability from Iraq to Venezuela.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iraq cannot afford to pay millions of workers and pensioners. Mexico’s grand plans to develop the country have been thrown into disarray. Ecuador is cutting government salaries, and Venezuela is on life support. Nigeria is seeking a nearly $7 billion emergency loan.

articles.headline: Protecting Workers From Coronavirus: OSHA Leaves It to Employers
articles.snippet: Critics say the federal agency charged with protecting worker safety has played a conspicuously small role during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Critics say the federal agency charged with protecting worker safety has played a conspicuously small role during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Ryan, a Target employee in Christiansburg, Va., has felt unsafe at work in recent weeks. He finds it difficult to follow the recommendation that he stay six feet away from others because the store is often crowded and customers linger closely while he restocks shelves.

articles.headline: Food, Rent, Health Insurance? Tough Choices in Pandemic Economy
articles.snippet: As items that were once necessities become luxuries, increasingly strapped Americans are re-evaluating what they spend and how.
articles.abstract: As items that were once necessities become luxuries, increasingly strapped Americans are re-evaluating what they spend and how.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two days before learning that she would lose her job, Lissa Gilliam spent hundreds of dollars online on baby products.

articles.headline: ‘Over All a Bit of Numbness Right Now’: One Cafe’s Fight for Virus Relief
articles.snippet: The story of OatMeals, a Greenwich Village hot cereal bar, shows how the damage inflicted on businesses might cast a long shadow on the future of the U.S. economy.
articles.abstract: The story of OatMeals, a Greenwich Village hot cereal bar, shows how the damage inflicted on businesses might cast a long shadow on the future of the U.S. economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samantha Stephens realized her longtime dream eight years ago, opening an oatmeal bar in Greenwich Village where customers can build bowls with toppings that range from chia seeds and berries to bacon and poached eggs. Now, the coronavirus has left the little company fighting for its life.

articles.headline: ‘Instead of Coronavirus, the Hunger Will Kill Us.’ A Global Food Crisis Looms.
articles.snippet: The world has never faced a hunger emergency like this, experts say. It could double the number of people facing acute hunger to 265 million by the end of this year.
articles.abstract: The world has never faced a hunger emergency like this, experts say. It could double the number of people facing acute hunger to 265 million by the end of this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — In the largest slum in Kenya’s capital, people desperate to eat set off a stampede during a recent giveaway of flour and cooking oil, leaving scores injured and two people dead.

articles.headline: The Untold Story of the Birth of Social Distancing
articles.snippet: The idea has been around for centuries. But it took a high school science fair, George W. Bush, history lessons and some determined researchers to overcome skepticism and make it federal policy.
articles.abstract: The idea has been around for centuries. But it took a high school science fair, George W. Bush, history lessons and some determined researchers to overcome skepticism and make it federal policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fourteen years ago, two federal government doctors, Richard Hatchett and Carter Mecher, met with a colleague at a burger joint in suburban Washington for a final review of a proposal they knew would be treated like a piñata: telling Americans to stay home from work and school the next time the country was hit by a deadly pandemic.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jennifer Steinhauer
